In-class Exercise 4: Spatial Weights and Applications: sf methods

Import packages

Show the code 
pacman::p_load(sf, spdep, tmap, tidyverse, knitr, GWmodel)
Show the code 
hunan <- st_read(dsn = "../../data/geospatial",
                 layer = "Hunan")
Reading layer `Hunan' from data source 
  `/Users/tangtang/Desktop/IS415 Geospatial Analytics and Applications/practice/is415gaa/data/geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'

Show the code 
hunan2012 <- read_csv("../../data/aspatial/Hunan_2012.csv")

Show the code 
hunan <- left_join(hunan, hunan2012) %>%
  select(1:4, 7,15)
Joining with `by = join_by(County)`

Working with Geographically Weighted Summary Statistics (GWSS)

The GWmodel package only works with sp objects, so we need to transform sf into sp

Show the code 
hunan_sp <- hunan %>% 
  as_Spatial()
  • kernel: similar to that in Spatial Point Pattern Analysis, smoothing out
Show the code 
gwstat <- gwss(data = hunan_sp,
               vars = "GDPPC",
               bw = 6,
               kernel = "bisquare",
               adaptive = TRUE,
               longlat = T)
gwstat
   ***********************************************************************
   *                       Package   GWmodel                             *
   ***********************************************************************

   ***********************Calibration information*************************

   Local summary statistics calculated for variables:
    GDPPC
   Number of summary points: 88
   Kernel function: bisquare 
   Summary points: the same locations as observations are used.
   Adaptive bandwidth: 6 (number of nearest neighbours)
   Distance metric: Great Circle distance metric is used.
